Expectation1: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation1: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I sat at my desk, the phone pressed to my ear, listening as Miriam and David excitedly described their vision for their wedding—over a year away, but they wanted to secure me as their rabbi now. I could hear the hope in their voices, the expectation that I would be there to guide them through this milestone. I promised to check my calendar, but as I hung up, my eyes drifted to the volunteer schedule tacked to the wall. My shift at the food pantry overlapped with the wedding date. Technically, other volunteers could cover the first hour if I arrived late, but I knew the expectation: be reliable, be on time. The pantry relied on consistency, and I prided myself on never letting them down. Yet, as a rabbi, I was entrusted with life’s most sacred moments. My heart twisted, caught between the joy of uniting two lives and the quiet, steadfast service to those in need. Both roles mattered deeply to me, and I felt the weight of their conflicting demands pressing in, unsure which path I would choose.
